persona.name: Jordan Alvarez-Kim

occupation.title: Sustainability / Urban Planning Analyst
occupation.description: Jordan works as a planning analyst focusing on sustainability, active transportation, and community engagement. Typical responsibilities include drafting sections of comprehensive plans, performing greenhouse gas emission inventories for municipal operations, coordinating with public works and transportation teams on bike-and-ped projects, writing grant applications to secure state/federal funding, and running neighborhood workshops to solicit input. They analyze traffic and land-use data (moderate familiarity with travel demand models), manage GIS layers for project proposals, prepare slide decks and public-facing materials, and attend city council and planning commission meetings to present findings. Key challenges include balancing political constraints, limited budget, competing stakeholder interests, and translating technical analysis into plain-language recommendations. Skills used daily: GIS, public presentation, grant writing, basic coding in Python for data cleanup, collaborative facilitation, budget scoping, and policy drafting. Works full-time (40 hours/week typical), occasionally evenings for community events, and earns in the $60k–$85k range annually (fits $50k-$99,999 bracket).

persona.residence: Portland, Oregon, United States (urban neighborhood, rents an apartment)
persona.education: Bachelor's degree in Urban and Regional Planning, Portland State University. Minor in Environmental Studies. Completed a year-long internship with a regional transportation planning office, certificate in GIS applications for planning, and a short professional certificate in public engagement and facilitation.
long_term_goals: Help their city cut greenhouse gas emissions in the transportation and building sectors by designing realistic policy and infrastructure interventions.
Advance into a leadership role at a municipal planning department or regional agency (Deputy Director / Program Manager) to shape long-term policy.
Buy a modest house in a walkable neighborhood or co-op in the Pacific Northwest within the next 6–10 years.
Build a small side consultancy to help small towns design climate-resilient adaptation plans.
Mentor younger trans and queer people entering planning, creating a small scholarship or mentorship program.
Maintain stable physical and mental health while balancing a meaningful job and a social life.
Retire with enough savings to travel for several months a year and spend winters in a milder climate.
Publish an accessible guide for community groups on how to influence local planning decisions effectively.
persona.style: Speech and mannerisms characterized by a calm, measured Pacific Northwest cadence with occasional code-switching into Spanish and Korean for family or cultural references. Jordan speaks in plain, inclusive language in public meetings, but with dry, self-deprecating humor in familiar company. Uses they/them pronouns in many contexts but predominantly uses she/her in professional settings (prefers 'she' but corrects politely when misgendered). Body language is composed: deliberate hand gestures when explaining a map, keeps good eye contact without staring. Typical outfit: layered, practical clothing — neutral-colored blazer or fleece over button shirts, durable ankle boots, and a reusable tote bag with a laptop and planner. Writes clear, structured emails with bullet points and action items, but occasionally leaves long, reflective messages to close friends. In high-stress meetings, Jordan taps a pen twice before speaking and often rephrases technical points to avoid jargon. Prefers small-group conversations to large networking events; when forced into large social settings, they circulate methodically, focusing on conversations that have clear purpose. Has a modest, curated social media presence (LinkedIn for professional, occasional Instagram stories about hikes or neighborhood meals).

traits: Conscientious and organized — prefers lists, timelines, and agendas.
Empathetic — reads room well and prioritizes inclusive processes.
Pragmatic idealist — believes in measurable progress rather than purity tests.
Detail-oriented — notices small inconsistencies in data or proposals.
Mildly anxious — prepares extensively to manage performance nerves.
Collaborative — enjoys co-creating plans with colleagues and community members.
Wry sense of humor — often undercuts tension with a dry one-liner.
Cautious with trust — makes friends slowly but loyally supports them.
Curious — loves learning new technical tools or community strategies.
Values integrity — dislikes performative gestures or greenwashing.
Adaptive — can pivot strategies when political realities demand it.
Skeptical of simple narratives — prefers nuanced solutions.
personality.personality_notes: Jordan scores high on openness and conscientiousness — creative but structured. They are moderately introverted; public-facing work exhausts them but they perform well when prepared. Agreeableness is high in collaborative settings but they can be firm and assertive when defending community priorities. Neuroticism is moderate: they experience anxiety before big presentations and sometimes ruminate, but they also have coping routines (exercise, calls with a close friend) that keep it functional.

interests: Active transportation (biking and walking infrastructure details and advocacy)
Small-scale urban gardening and native plant landscaping
Data visualization for public audiences (maps, simple charts)
Local history and how neighborhoods evolved
Hiking the Columbia River Gorge and weekend trail outings
Cooking fusion food — blending Korean and Mexican flavors
Affordable, community-led housing models (co-ops, ADUs)
Listening to policy and environmental podcasts (e.g., 'The Climate Weekly', 'Strong Towns' episodes)
Independent bookstores and literary fiction (favorite sections: urban studies and travel memoirs)
Documentary films on cities and climate
Cycling maintenance and fixing flats (can change a tube in under 15 minutes)
Sustainable fashion: buys second-hand and mends clothes
Minimalist home organization (open to small, functional decor)
Learning grassroots organizing tactics and meeting facilitation
Photography — takes street-level photos for community outreach materials
Board games with strategy and cooperation (co-op games like Pandemic)
Local coffee culture and supporting small roasters
Volunteerism — serves on neighborhood advisory committees
Language learning — working on conversational Korean and improving Spanish idioms
Travel to culturally significant places — enjoys slow travel over tourist itineraries
Gardening podcasts and YouTube channels for native plants
DIY home repairs at a basic level — confident with paint, shelving, and sealing gaps
Environmental justice literature and case studies
Neighborhood-level data analysis — tracking metrics like walkability scores
Bike commuting year-round when weather permits
likes: Black Americano or oat-milk latte (prefers Americano on busy mornings)
Stumptown and local roasters' single-origin brews
Light rain and cool weather for long walks
Farmers' markets with local produce and small baker stalls
Late-afternoon tea with a slice of pan dulce or mochi
Neighborhood potlucks and civic dinners
Small, independent restaurants that post ingredients and sourcing
Podcasts and long-form interviews about policy and design
Clear, concise public presentations with mapped visuals
Plain, practical shoes — good boots for storms and errands
Friends who are direct and emotionally available
Houseplants that survive neglect (snake plants, pothos)
Libraries with community programs and a good local archive
Reusable everything — mugs, utensils, cloth produce bags
Music playlists that mix indie folk, low-key electronic, and old-school R&B
Movies that make them think — documentaries and thoughtful dramas
Skill-sharing workshops (bike repair, canning, basic carpentry)
Volunteer shifts that produce tangible outcomes
Writing letters to the editor or public comments when a project has flaws
Neighborhood walks to notice small details about streetscapes
dislikes: Performative environmentalism (greenwashing)
Overly glossy marketing that hides negative impacts
Unpredictable public meeting formats where residents are ignored
High-pressure networking events with forced small talk
Fast-fashion retailers and single-use apparel
Excessively technical jargon in public-facing materials
Cars parked on sidewalks or blocking bike lanes
Late replies to important collaborative emails
Crowded, loud nightclubs (prefers quieter social venues)
Pop-up chains replacing long-standing neighborhood businesses
When people assume they are a subject-matter expert on everything because they work in government
Shallow social media arguments that replace sustained advocacy
Poorly designed public spaces that ignore accessibility
Gentrification that displaces long-time residents
Being misgendered intentionally or treated as an ‘educational’ curiosity
Wasteful single-use giveaways at events
Overly authoritarian tone in public policy communications
Tokenizing marginalized voices rather than supporting real power
Unrepaired potholes on frequently used bike corridors
Being interrupted repeatedly in meetings

tv_and_streaming: A small set of serialized dramas (prefers character-driven over spectacle)
books_and_authors: Jane Jacobs (familiar with 'The Death and Life of Great American Cities')
Contemporary fiction about migration and identity
Practical policy guides and case studies
entertainment_and_media.social_media_habits: Moderate screen time: uses streaming services for shows and documentaries, follows a handful of professional LinkedIn groups and Instagram accounts for local roasters or plant sellers. Less dependent on social media; avoids Twitter-style flame wars, rarely posts political hot takes but shares community event information.

beliefs: Climate change is real, urgent, and requires both mitigation and adaptation at the city level.
Local government is where practical, everyday climate action can have measurable impact.
Transportation policy is one of the most cost-effective levers to reduce emissions and improve equity.
Affordable housing is inseparable from sustainable urban policy — displacement undermines climate goals.
Community engagement must be genuine and structured to include historically marginalized voices.
Evidence-based policy is essential but must be translated into accessible formats for the public.
Pragmatic compromises are necessary: perfectionism can stall progress.
Green infrastructure (street trees, permeable pavement) provides multiple public health benefits.
Public funds should prioritize projects with demonstrable equity outcomes.
People respond better to positive, concrete benefits (shorter commutes, safer streets) than abstract environmental messaging.
Small pilot projects are valuable for testing interventions before scaling.
Data transparency builds trust: public dashboards and open-source data are worth the investment.
Regenerative approaches to urban design (soil health, native plants) are underrated.
Procurement processes need reform to favor small, local contractors and resilient materials.
Elections matter: although local, they set the agenda for streets and services.
Democracy in the U.S. is somewhat threatened by misinformation and polarization; civic institutions must be defended.
Independent politics can help bridge gridlock if rooted in strong local coalitions.
Support for targeted gun control measures (closing gun show loopholes, red flag laws) can reduce risk without blanket bans.
Public servants should be held to high ethical standards and be responsive to constituents.
Technology helps with data and outreach, but it cannot replace face-to-face relationship building.
There is value in learning from small towns and international examples for scalable, low-cost solutions.
Privileging short-term developer profits over long-term community resilience is a policy failure.
Workplace diversity and inclusion are not optional — they improve program outcomes.
Mental health supports for public employees are necessary to avoid burnout in sectors with heavy emotional labor.
Personal consumption choices matter but must be contextualized within systems-level change.
There should be a stronger social safety net to allow people to participate in civic life (paid leave, living wages).
Local businesses are community anchors — policy should support them rather than enable displacement.
Public space design should center accessibility: disability rights are central, not an add-on.
Transit investments must be paired with anti-displacement strategies.
The voices of long-term residents should carry weight in neighborhood decisions.
Funding for community-led initiatives yields higher trust and better outcomes than top-down projects.
There is skepticism toward purely market-driven sustainability solutions without regulation and accountability.
Green jobs training programs should be accessible to people from varied educational backgrounds.
Holding local governments accountable through informed voting and civic participation is critical.
Fiscal responsibility matters; projects must balance ambition with long-term maintenance costs.
Urban plants and trees should be prioritized when they demonstrably reduce heat islands in low-income neighborhoods.
Carbon offsets are often insufficient and can be misused; direct emission reductions are preferable.
Personal privacy must be protected when deploying sensor networks and urban data collection.
skills: Competent in ArcGIS and QGIS for mapping and spatial analysis.
Basic Python for data cleaning and automating repetitive tasks (pandas, geopandas familiarity).
Proficient in Excel (pivot tables), Google Sheets, and data visualization tools (Tableau, DataWrapper).
Experienced facilitator for community workshops, trained in creating inclusive agendas and breakout exercises.
Grant writing experience for state and federal programs (Transportation Alternatives, FEMA mitigation grants).
Public speaking: delivers clear, visual presentations to councils and neighborhood groups.
Grant and project budgeting: scoping costs, identifying funding streams, and tracking expenditures.
Bilingual conversational competency (Spanish and intermediate Korean); can do community outreach in Spanish comfortably.
Basic bike mechanics and maintenance; can perform routine repairs and encourage ridership.
Conflict mediation skills within stakeholder groups; skilled at finding pragmatic compromises.
Report writing and policy drafting with attention to clear outcomes and measurable indicators.
Community outreach through both digital and in-person channels — mailing lists, pop-up info tables.
Time management and project planning: creates Gantt-style timelines and keeps cross-departmental tasks on track.
Familiarity with environmental assessment processes and local permitting pathways.
Volunteer coordination: organizes volunteers for community events and data collection.

general: Arrives early to public meetings to set up materials and greet participants.
Keeps a paper planner and a digital calendar synchronized; uses color-coding for priorities.
Prepares talking points and a two-minute 'elevator brief' for each public presentation.
Takes notes by hand during listening sessions, later transcribing into digital summaries.
Recharges with a 30–45 minute walk each day, often while listening to a podcast.
Brings reusable utensils and a refillable water bottle everywhere.
When stressed, brews a double Americano and goes outside for fresh air.
Checks municipal email in the morning and early evening only — tries to avoid constant work notifications.
Says 'thank you' and follows up with action items after meetings.
Maintains a small but reliable network of peers for technical troubleshooting and emotional support.

morning: Wakes between 6:30–7:30 AM depending on whether there is an early site visit.
Quick stretch or 20-minute yoga routine most mornings.
Prepares coffee (Americano or oat latte on special days) and a simple breakfast — avocado toast or yogurt with granola.
Glances at email and calendar to confirm the day's schedule and any required materials.
Checks regional transit alerts if commuting by bike or light rail.
workday: Blocks mornings for focused analytical work (mapping, grant drafts, data clean-up).
Schedules community meetings and outreach in afternoons or evenings when residents can attend.
Lunch is often a short walk to a nearby cafe; uses lunch to clear their head or run quick neighborhood errands.
Holds one-on-one check-ins weekly with direct supervisor and biweekly with project teams.
Leaves notes for follow-up items and updates a shared project tracker every day.
evening: Attends community meetings 1–2 nights per week (may run workshops or take notes).
Cooking dinner from scratch at least 4 nights a week; experiments with new fusion recipes on weekends.
Spends 30–60 minutes reading (policy reports, fiction, or community newsletters).
Calls a close friend or family member twice weekly for longer conversations.
Unplugs screens an hour before bed when possible, prefers reading or knitting to wind down.
weekend: Longer local hikes or day trips to coastal areas or regional parks.
Volunteer shift or attending a neighborhood potluck once a month.
Works on a small personal project (DIY home repair, plant propagation, or freelance mapping for a community group).
Visits a farmer's market and meets neighbors, sometimes bringing back snacks for friends.
If not traveling, explores a new small restaurant or coffee roaster.

health.physical_health: Generally good. Has mild seasonal asthma controlled with an as-needed inhaler and avoids smoky conditions. Maintains moderate fitness through regular walking, weekend hikes, and occasional yoga. No children; no major chronic illnesses. Has had minor surgery (appendectomy in late teens).
health.mental_health: Managed anxiety — uses a combination of therapy (biweekly CBT-inspired sessions), mindfulness practice, and exercise. Has experienced workplace stress and mild burnout in a previous role; learned to set clearer boundaries and use accrued leave. No history of severe depressive episodes requiring hospitalization.
health.gender_affirming_health: Underwent social transition several years ago; on hormone replacement therapy supervised by a primary care provider. Has a supportive clinician and accesses trans-competent care within the region. Has updated legal name and some identification but is still in the process of changing certain documents.
health.substance_use: Drinks socially (1–3 drinks on occasion), does not smoke tobacco, avoids recreational drugs except for rare cannabis use when with friends.
health.preventive_care: Up to date on routine vaccinations, annual physical, dental checkups, and mental-health follow-ups. Engages in regular skin checks and basic self-care routines.

relationships.name: Marisol Alvarez (mother)
relationships.description: Lives in a nearby suburb; first-generation immigrant from Mexico. Warm but occasionally worried about Jordan's career and safety. They talk every 7–10 days; Marisol cooks traditional meals and shares cultural knowledge. Jordan is financially supportive enough to help with occasional bills.

relationships.name: David Kim (father)
relationships.description: Korean-American, lives across the country. Quiet, pragmatic; more reserved about discussions of gender but trying to learn and be supportive. Phone calls every few weeks. Has good technical skills and helps Jordan with basic coding questions sometimes.

relationships.name: Ari Tran (close friend)
relationships.description: College friend and current roommate until Jordan moves to their own place. Works in nonprofit communications; shares many civic interests. They coordinate volunteer events and debrief over hikes.

relationships.name: Leah Park (mentor/colleague)
relationships.description: Senior planner in the same department who sponsors Jordan's projects occasionally and gives career advice. Occasionally meets for coffee to prep for presentations.

relationships.name: Neighborhood advisory committee
relationships.description: An informal network of 6–8 neighbors, mostly long-term residents and small-business owners, who collaborate on local street improvements and safety audits. Jordan convenes and summarizes their input into official reports.

relationships.name: Medical and therapeutic team
relationships.description: Primary care provider, endocrinologist (for hormone therapy), and a therapist — the team coordinates Jordan's physical and mental health needs.

other_facts: Born in Sacramento, California; family moved to Oregon when Jordan was 10.

Family background is mixed: mother is Mexican-born (Alvarez), father is Korean-American (Kim); bilingual household growing up with Spanish and English, and occasional Korean visits from paternal relatives.
Chose the hyphenated Alvarez-Kim as a deliberate identity statement connecting both sides of their family.
Undergraduate senior capstone project mapped food deserts and proposed micro-incentive programs for corner stores to stock fresh produce.
Ran a small campus bike-repair pop-up during college finals week to raise funds for a student transit pass program.
Campaigned for safer bike lanes in college town; first successful victory was a protected lane pilot on a busy corridor.
Was the first in the immediate family to attend and graduate from college in the U.S.
Has no children and is currently single by choice — focusing on career and community commitments.
Went through a legal name change and updated social security card and some IDs; passport change still pending due to appointment backlogs.
Experienced a period of significant financial strain in their mid-20s while paying student loans and doing unpaid internships; developed a strict budget and now has an emergency fund.
Keeps a small balcony garden with native sedges and a potted Korean pear sapling.
Has one adopted cat named 'Miso' (short, affectionate companion; helps with routines and emotional grounding).
Proud moment: delivered a clear, mapped presentation at a contentious community meeting and calmed the debate enough for a productive compromise.
Regret: a public comment period years ago was mishandled when Jordan deferred too much to political leadership; still thinks about how they might have pushed harder for community safeguards.
Embarrassing anecdote: once misspoke city code numbers in a live council meeting and made an awkward joke to diffuse tension — it worked and is now an oft-repeated story among staff.
Collected field notes in a spiral notebook for years — has dozens of maps with coffee stains.
Has moderate student loan debt with a plan to accelerate payments once savings goals are met.
Used to play guitar in college, semi-competent but prefers listening to music now; pulls it out occasionally at small gatherings.
Keeps a folder of community drawings and thank-you notes from residents; these are pinned to a corkboard in the living room.
Attended a neighborhood mutual aid training during the pandemic and helped coordinate grocery drops to elderly neighbors.
Once backpacked solo through Oaxaca for two weeks; learned to cook with local women and improved Spanish fluency.
Has simple rituals for high-stress days: packing a thermos of strong coffee, bringing a printed map, and texting Ari the meeting start time.
Holds a small emergency kit in the apartment with bike repair tools, a compact rain poncho, and an extra phone charger.
Is registered to vote in local and state elections and volunteers occasionally at polling sites during municipal elections.
Participated in a regional climate fellowship program that broadened professional contacts and provided access to technical mentors.
Keeps an old camera and prefers shooting black-and-white street photos of neighborhoods undergoing change.
Has a long-term savings target for a home down payment and a separate modest retirement account; conservative about investment risk.
Enjoys collaborative cooking nights where friends prepare dishes representing their family histories.
Has a small tattoo on the inner wrist that combines a map grid and a tiny tree — a personal reminder of place and stewardship.
Was a peer counselor in college through a multicultural student center and still does informal peer support.
Has a low tolerance for sustained authoritarian leadership styles in organizations; left an earlier job partly because of managerial misconduct.
Is on the mailing list for three local neighborhood associations and reads their minutes regularly to stay informed.
Feels most energized when a project results in a small, tangible improvement for people who use a street every day.
Keeps a spreadsheet of ongoing community requests and follows up until there is closure — a private workflow habit.
Has a modest side habit of collecting vintage transit maps and swapping them with friends.
Plans to someday publish a practical 'how-to' for neighborhood groups on navigating municipal funding cycles.
Values small daily pleasures (good coffee, a clean pair of socks, a neighbor's smile) as essential to wellbeing.
Has periodically experienced microaggressions at work tied to gender identity; addresses them directly or through HR depending on the context.

Believes that representation in planning matters and has worked to recruit interns from local community colleges into unpaid or low-paid roles — has been trying to shift that practice toward paid gigs.
